awd_titl_txt: On the Formation and Destruction of Giant Molecular Clouds in Galaxies
awd_abstract_narration:
If we are to understand how the Sun and Earth formed, we must first understand how the Galaxy itself was formed and how it changes over time.  Astronomers know that the Milky Way Galaxy contains huge clouds of gas and dust.  It is from these "Giant Molecular Clouds" (GMCs) that all stars are born.  The goal of this project is to understand how these giant clouds are formed and how they change over millions of years.  Using computer models developed over a number of years, the awardee will investigate how the explosions of very large stars affect the clouds.  The models include many of the things known to affect the gas in the Milky Way: the temperature and density of the gas, the rotation of the Milky Way, the light from the billions of stars in the galaxy, and even the chemistry of the atoms and molecules in the clouds.  Much of the work will be done by a postdoctoral researcher, guided by the Principal Investigator (PI) who is a world-renown expert in Milky Way astronomy and the birth of stars.  Graduate and undergraduate students will also be involved in the research, and female high-school students will be invited to the PI's institute to shadow graduates and early-career scientists.  In this way the PI hopes to inspire a new generation of young, female researchers.

The project seeks to continue numerical modeling of star formation on very large spatial scales (GMCs and above).  The new models will include ionizing and non-ionizing UV radiation, supernova feedback, turbulence, magnetic fields, chemistry, and galactic shear.  Many of these effects have been excluded from past models or used individually rather than in combination.  This project will use advanced computational methods to simulate GMC formation and destruction, providing the first fully self-consistent magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) and radiation MHD models at high resolution and with comprehensive treatment of physics and chemistry.  Such modeling is useful not only in synthesizing star formation and GMC evolution in the Milky Way Galaxy but may also be used to interpret new ALMA observations of other, nearby galaxies.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, the PI Eve Ostriker (Princeton) worked with undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers to study the lifecycle of the giant molecular clouds (GMCs) that are the sites of star formation in our Milky Way and other galaxies.  The project took aim at quantitatively predicting how "feedback" from recently-formed stars -- in the form of stellar radiation and winds -- can halt further star formation in a cloud by ionizing, heating, and pushing on the surrounding gas to disperse the parent GMC.  These models quantify the "self-regulation" theory of  star formation in GMCs, making predictions for the fraction of a given cloud that will eventually collapse gravitationally to make stars (this fraction is known as the star formation  efficiency -- SFE), and the complementary fraction of the cloud that will be dispersed due to the effects of stellar feedback. 

The team's studies required supercomputer simulations to solve the equations of gas dynamics including gravity and feedback effects, and intercompared results for many different models to understand how the conditions in the GMC (such as the level of turbulence and strength of magnetic fields) affect the SFE and other outcomes, including cloud lifetimes.  The simulations predict that ultraviolet radiation is able to prevent runaway star formation and disperse all but a few percent of the mass in  a GMC, provided it is not too strongly bound initially. The team's predictions of photoevaporation of GMCs due to ultraviolet starlight is consistent with what is seen in observations of clouds such as Orion and the Eagle nebula in the Milky  Way, as well as observations in other nearby galaxies.

The team's simulations show that stellar winds have much less significant impact than previously thought since most of the wind energy is lost to cooling.  To interpret  their computational simulations, the team developed an analytic theory of how energy is lost in unstable, turbulent, fractal interfaces when shocked wind gas at millions of degrees mixes with much denser gas and then radiates away energy rapidly.  Previous more idealized models failed to predict the energy loss of winds because they did not include a turbulent, fractal interface.  The loss of hot gas in turbulent interfaces also provides an answer to the longstanding puzzle of why so little X-ray emission has been observed from wind bubbles around young star clusters.

The team's computational chemistry models made predictions to calibrate the relationship between emission from carbon monoxide (CO) and molecular hydrogen (H_2) in a range of galactic environments.  The CO-H_2 calibration can be used to obtain the mass of GMCs based on observations of millimeter-wave emission with the ALMA millimeter array facility built and managed by the NSF. 

Developing new computational modeling techniques was a major part of the team's effort, and crucial to the new results that were obtained.  The new software tools developed as part of this project will be used by members of the team and other  researchers in future work.   The training of undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers via this project will be extremely valuable to their future careers in academia, national laboratories, and industry.

  • Giant molecular clouds are the birthplace of stars. Because stars irradiate their surroundings, stellar formation leads to destruction of the parent cloud. This process is seen in numerical models, where ionized gas (right) is photoevaporated from surfaces of the molecular gas (left).

  • Massive stars produce powerful winds, which create hot bubbles in the surrounding cloud. Dynamical instabilities at the fractal surface of the bubble lead to mixing and subsequent cooling, as shown in outputs from numerical models.

    Copyrighted

    Stellar Wind Bubble

This H_2 has very faint emission, and astronomers must use emission from CO (3rd, 4th row) as a alternative tracer. Our numerical models provide a key calibration of the H_2 - CO relation.
